body:
Your videos do not provide reproduction steps. Also linking a 2 hour video is not very useful nor is a video where you are just playing a game. If you want to link a video, link one where you are specifically replicating the issue and thats it.

"Plug in an analog audio device" An input device? An output device?

Are you saying that this only ever happens when you plug your speakers/headphones/other output device in during the same session?

Given you provide no insight into your PA config its pretty hard to say anything about your setup or potential bug. Provide the log from obs and the output from `pacmd info` while OBS is targeting the wrong device. But this sounds like a case of your system is misconfigured.

Hi @kkartaltepe,

I'm fairly sure this is not related to a system misconfiguration, but is a bug related to how OBS detects and recognizes audio devices on Linux/Ubuntu. 

Especially troubling is the fact that the issue resolves itself after changing the OBS "Desktop Audio" device away from and back to "Default". This likely would not be the case if this was a simple system misconfiguration issue. 

As far as video not providing reproduction steps, I did not anticipate it being difficult for a reader to watch the first 60 seaconds of a video and read a 5 step list showing how this state was achieved. 

(Twitch mutes audio by default, please un-mute and listen of course, due to the nature of the bug.)

If anyone is having trouble with this, I would be more than happy to provide further clarification.

I'm not _entirely_ certain whether the order of devices plugged in or the time of it appears to matter during the use session, but it appears the issue recurs regardless of these variables. It happens most often during the beginning of a use session after restarting the computer or switching settings profiles, independent of which settings profile I use. Hence why I consider this bug reproducible. 

If I can catch the  issue again, I'll provide some logs. 

This issue has occured _**numerous**_ times to me (including one time where I was having a private conversation on the phone giving my Social Security Number and it was picked up by the 'Desktop Audio' of the stream towards Twitch due to this bug), and I'm pretty certain it's a bug with OBS/Linux that may need some attention.

Without the requested information, it is not possible to replicate the exact conditions. I've tested this numerous times on my Linux test system and cannot replicate the behavior you describe.

When reporting an issue, if the people you are reporting it to are asking for additional information "I don't think this is the problem" is not exactly a great response. We're asking for more information because we aren't able to replicate the issue. If you're unwilling to provide the basic log file and configuration information, then I will close this issue out.

Hi, thanks @Fenrirthviti,

Sorry to hear this couldn't be replicated.

I can provide log file and configurations, and will also especially try to snag some logs if I catch this again.

Please keep this issue open for a bit to faccilitate this on my end, and also give me more time to try and catch the issue occurring again.
It's happening again right now, I'm going to try and get some logs

@Fenrirthviti @kkartaltepe Here it is:

https://obsproject.com/logs/bphrRvlH2GUuEJko
"and the output from pacmd info"
And to clarify you actually did the fix in the log you provided? (reselected default and it selected the right output?)
https://gist.github.com/mkrupczak3/f547b83622f9336ce2c2d883d91d2cd0
Did not clarify in the log that I provided, because it was just the one that my client made available automagically.

Let me rephase the question.

During the session where you uploaded the log, did you reselect the default audio device to get it to select the correct device?
No
My OBS crashed before I was able to do that
Should I upload another log if I am able to do that?

Log file of the application while performing correctly expected behavior:

https://obsproject.com/logs/mk4RbT663xdrYvMO

Another video showing some of my OBS application/audio setup and describing the issue (while OBS is operating correctly):
https://www.twitch.tv/videos/691561534
I'll likely encounter it again within the next day or so, I'll try and upload a log that includes me performing the "workaround steps" by switching to and from the default on the "Desktop Audio".

In both the reported bad log and the reported good log OBS default audio attempts to record from
'alsa_output.usb-Creative_Technology_Ltd_Sound_Blaster_E1_0000021225-00.analog-stereo.monitor'

As such it seems like the issue is indeed in your configuration or other software which might redirect OBS to other devices.

This issue has existed well before I've been using the "sound blaster" device. 

Regardless, The setting of "default audio" for desktop should _never_ pickup a microphone device, this is completely outside of intended behavior and still warrants investigation as a bug. 

About half of my streaming again today was messed up because of this bug, if I'm able to catch it I'll try to submit a log. 

I would appreciate it if you could suspend your disbelief that it's simply due to a system misconfiguration, if only for a moment. Belive it or not I used to work with computers for a living; I'm using a LTS version of Ubuntu, and very basic USB microphone and USB/analog audio. This is most definitely an issue with OBS.

Its not outside the realm of possibility, recording your desktop requires OBS to create a monitor which is the same kind of PA device as your microphone. You can start `pavucontrol` on your own system and and forcibly change OBS's desktop audio from the monitor device to any recording device (including your mics) yourself.

Likely some variation of this is happening and something on your system is doing a similar redirection. This is intentionally transparent in PA to allow you to redirect software that might not let you chose the right device. And as such there is nothing we can do in OBS if we choose the right device and some other software on your system redirects it, thats OBS working as intended and requires you reconfigure your system to stop doing that.

Its not like I dont believe this issue is happening to you, I simply asking you to do everything you can to make sure what I describe is not the case. Since I cannot replicate this on my own LTS version of ubuntu with a basic microphone and analog audio, there is not much more I personally can do to investigate the issue with the information currently available. That's why we rely on you to provide as much detail as possible about the issue and more specifically to provide replication steps that work as consistently as possible.

I see this issue as well, using PipeWire 0.3.30 and PulseEffects 5.0.4.  I believe this happens with PulseEffects specifically.  I'm including context to rationalize that belief.

Relevant information for reproducing the issue:

- In PulseEffects, an equalizer effect is on my output and a noise reduction effect is on my input.
- In PulseEffects settings "General" tab, "Process All Outputs" and "Process All Inputs" are enabled.
- In PulseEffects settings "PipeWire" tab, "Input Effects" and "Output Effects" are both set to "Use Default"
- PipeWire default sink is set to "Built-in Audio Analog Stereo".
    - This is my motherboard's audio output with a 3.5mm jack.
- PipeWire default source is set to "Audio Adapter (Unitek Y-247A Mono)".
    - This is a small USB audio adapter I use for cleaner input.
- In OBS settings, "Desktop Audio" is set to "Default".
- In OBS settings, "Mic/Auxiliary Audio" is set to "Default".
- In `pavucontrol` "Recording" tab, "OBS Desktop Audio from" is set to "PulseEffects source".
    - The workaround of manually changing this from "PulseEffects source" to "Monitor of Built-in Audio Analog Stereo" fixes the issue for that particular OBS session.
        - The issue comes back on any new session of OBS, so the workaround is currently necessary every time OBS starts.

The issue seems obvious to me.  My rationale is below.

- In OBS settings, "Desktop Audio" being set to "Default" is using "PulseEffects source", which is a microphone-related input source, not a monitor of a sink (output).
    - Instead, OBS "Desktop Audio" being set to "Default" should use "Monitor of [default sink]".  In my case, this is "Monitor of Built-in Audio Analog Stereo".
